newsitem.title: UK: October IPE Brent sags at close with US gasoline.
newsitem.headline: October IPE Brent sags at close with US gasoline.

text.p: IPE October Brent shed gains in a late sell-off to finish in negative territory after market leader U.S. gasoline lost impetus.
October Brent ended down eight cents at $19.08 a barrel after hitting an afternoon peak of $19.40.
The expiring September Brent contract finished 20 cents higher on the day at $19.19 a barrel.
Dealers said prices had scaled back after a cent a gallon gain on the leading U.S. unleaded gasoline contract disappeared.
"Gasoline is still the leader but the bulls didn't quite have the taste for it again today," said a broker.
"There's some concern that gasoline might be due for a correction (lower)," said another.
An outage of Exxon's Baytown, Texas gasoline-making catalytic cracking unit had helped lend support to U.S. gasoline on Wednesdayu and encouraged speculative buying.
Weekly oil inventory data released on Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute for the week ended August 8 showed U.S. gasoline stocks near historical lows for the time of year.
But an open arbitrage from Europe is starting to attract cross Atlantic gasoline sales, traders said.
Dealers noted that other oil contracts already were becoming increasingly reluctant to follow prompt NYMEX gasoline's premium over the rest of the market.
They said that from a technical standpoint, measuring RSIs and stochastics, IPE oil futures remained neutral to positive.
Earlier IPE gas oil for September ended up $3.75 near the day's high and at a steady $4.09 premium over Brent.
Gas oil traders said plentiful supplies in European storage prevented any early possibility of a run-up in gas oil premiums over crude.
